reviews.review_msg: horrible please do not take him at all. disorganized and expects you to think his class is the only one you're taking because he always fails to upload lectures and quizzes on time and cancels quizzes instead. makes last minute decisions without telling students. he was unreachable most of the times we got the department involved. he needs help

In the interest of Dr. Prefontaine and his potential students, he should never be allowed to teach again. Incompetent, arrogant, and unprofessional. Everything is posted late or not at all, grading criteria makes no sense. Wish he taught as well as he made excuses. Skipped his own class because he was under "cYbEr aTtacK". AVOID AT ALL COSTS!!!!!!!

Honestly, if you wish to pass this course avoid this professor. I'm unsure if he's like this in previous semester's but I know for sure the 80 students taking 324 this semester believes that he's not fitting to be a professor. AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

DO NOT TAKE CLASSES WITH GRATIEN. Please trust me on this. He is extremely disorganized, doesn't post lecture material on time, is very unfriendly and extremely unhelpful, teaches the course through academic papers, etc. Half way through the semester students in my class got the Health Sciences director involved because of his inability to teach.

Horrible professor. Incredibly disorganized, does not show care for his students (or his job, for that matter), swears in lecture, easily frustrated, and by far the worse professor Ive ever learned from at SFU. His lectures slides are sometimes incomplete, and he just reads off of the slides. If I could give a 0 I would.

WORST PROF EVER!! SUPER UNORGANIZED, LAZY AND COMMUNICATES EMAILS IN 5 WORDS OR LESS. UPLOADS LECTURE SLIDES VERY LATE, QUIZZES ALL SHORT ANSWER, INFOGRAPHIC PROJECT WITH UNCLEAR INSTRUCTIONS, EXAMS ALL PARAGRAPH ANSWERS WITH A TIME LIMIT. VERY RUDE AND DOESNT LIKE ANSWERING QUESTIONS AND GETS FRUSTRATED EASILY! AVOID AND SAVE UR MENTAL HEALTH!!!!
avoid this professor at all costs

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS with this Prof. He is dull, boring and one lecture just "chose" to not have lecture slides when you cannot even hear him. Do yourself a favour, take it with Mark. I promise you, it will turn out better. I think the other reviews rating him positive were not even made by students.

Dr. Prefontaine was very personable during lectures and you could tell he was very interested about population and evolutionary genetics. He was sometimes hard to follow during lecture, but he was more than willing to clarify in office hours or after class, or even if you ran into him in the hallway.

I actually thoroughly enjoyed taking this class with him, the topics are interesting and he does a good job explaining concepts, he is also very willing to answer questions or clarify anything you don't understand. I would recommend him! One of my fav HSCI courses so far.

Topics of his lecture were interesting. He made some jokes and tried his best to explain his lecture contents easily. However, about 90% of mark is composed of weekly quiz and test. Thus, I think he needs to change this marking scheme as soon as possible. And, he should know more of his own materials. This class is a "Not recommended."

I was skeptical at first since the negative comments stuck out. I think he's a fantastic professor. He must have changed his teaching style and course breakdown. He's helpful if you ask for it. He encourages questions and the work load is very reasonable. Gained experience in analyzing scientific journal articles. Lovely prof; one of my favourites.

Do not take him if you require to be spoon-fed material, like in most HSCI classes. Course helped me master article assimilation from real scientific papers, and topics covered have stuck with me way better than obscure details obsessed about in MBB or BIOL. Appreciated help in covering tricky concepts, pretty good experience.

I was dreading this class from the comment posted below. But I think he had improved in teaching the material. I still needs to work on communicating the material but he more than willing to help and is very patient in explaining tricky concepts that are not clear during lecture. He really cares for the students and breaks down the important points

As a person, hes cool he made funny jokes, lol "gangsta" but he needs to improve his teaching ability and he needs to be more understanding in terms of the articles. He expects us to know so much material in full detail in less than 6 weeks, and he didn't seem to understand them himself anyway, so how could he expect us to? with no background info

I hated going to this class with a passion. Why does this course even exist? Absolute waste of time and money, it's amazing how SFU makes these little classes mandatory for our degrees....quick money grab
follw up my previous rating...I made a mistake the class should read HSCI 324 and not 321

Is this class for real? I have no idea what the purpose of this class is? Go over 25+ articles that he MORE THAN CLEARLY does not comprehend....and expects us to summarize them, learn them, understand them COMPLETELY when he hasnt even taught a single useful thing in this course. Avoid at all costs! I want my money back
very disorganized, lecture slides are the shortest ever seen
Dr. Pokrishevsky is an amazing prof. The lectures were clear and he was super helpful.

Eddie wasn't the best. He's very hard to understand in class and basically reads off of slides, so most people never showed up. His midterm and final were fair but were graded too harshly. His 3 take-home assignments are difficult and have nothing to do with the midterm/final. Overall very mediocre - avoid having him if you can!

A nice prof, but sometimes he talks too fast and hard to understand what he is saying. Midterm and final were fair, 3 take home assignments were easy marks. There are weekly quizzes, which helped to keep up with material but overall the course was a lot of work. However, he offers help through emails and you can do a bonus presentation for extra2%

Dr. Pokrishevsky was by no means a poor professor. The biggest issue I had with him was simply that, if you missed class, lecture slides were far too complicated in order to catch up on your own and understand what was important. The weekly quizzes were also annoying, especially when taking 5 courses.

Very Nice prof,, but spoke too quiet and fast in class. He was helpful if you emailed or went to him. His lectures were very dense, lots of slides. His assignments were very tough, you had to go to outside sources for help (academic articles). MT was challenging, but the final was much easier & quizzes each wk which were simple. need to put effort

Kind and knowledgeable professor. The class requires a lot of work, but I certainly learned a lot about human genetics and evolution. If too quiet - ask him to turn up the mike, and go to his office hours. Very funny.

Expect amount of assignments you've never seen before in upper division. Asks dull questions that are either specific or just require large amount of work for no reason. Tests don't encourage understanding but rather plain memorization, overall makes the course way harder than it is. Take at your own risk

He's a nice person but does not teach well. He skips through important aspects of lecture. Asks questions we haven't seen before on HW and weekly quizzes. If you have a full course load, STAY AWAY from this class and prof. Makes you work SO HARD for a good grade. Approachable but doesn't clearly answer questions. YOU ARE ON YOUR OWN
Doesn't know how to teach and doesn't teach us what we need to know, but seems like a nice guy. Zooms through the lectures. Don't make the mistake of taking upper division classes with him.

grading breaks down to: hw, quizzes, group project. hw is pretty essy to do well in, quizzes can get tricky but again, easy to do well as you can work with classmates, group project can be marked a bit hardhly, but i guess it's still a better alternative than a final exam. mark was so sweet and so engaging, super passionate about his teaching.

I loved mark but this class, idk. Teaching style was wonky, I didnt like the fact that we had to watch online lectures and then COME to lecture again. Then again, very easy to do well. The quizzes were sometimes challenging but you can do them with the entire class and share answers so come for that. as a person, mark is very nuanced and inspiring.

Prof Lechner is very respectful in terms of the way he teaches specific topics and is very passionate about his lessons. You'll need to listen to the recordings to dissect and study graphs in details in order to do well on the weekly quizzes. Assignments weren't difficult plus term project that you choose the topic for. Pay attention to succeed.
Best prof at SFU!
One of the best professors I have ever had. Gives me hope for HSCI courses. Spectacular Professor.

Dr. Lechner is amazing. He is available after classes, answers emails quickly, and shows that he cares about his student's education above all else. I would love to take more classes with him; great lecturer, even better person.

Course content is dry at times and very difficult and heavy, but he does a pretty good job at teaching. He posts old and new lecture recordings which helps a lot because some of the stuff is hard to grasp right away. He's a nice dude and he replies to e-mails super quick every single time.

one of the nicest profs at sfu. I found the content quite hard to understand but his lectures and the weekly homework made it manageable. his instructions are super clear and always available for extra help. there are no midterms or final and quizzes are collaborative which probably the best part of this class. would definitely take him again.

Echo what everyone else said.
Mark was one of 3 HSCI profs who bothered to show up for HSCI graduation and to talk to students. That tells you what type of prof he is. One of the most brilliant profs in SFU, you have to put the work in to fully understand his class. I was very impressed with his game wheel thing for class.

Interesting to learn about human origin and none can teach it better than Mark. Honestly, do your homework ahead of time, pick your group members wisely and study for the weekly quizzes. Don't lag behind with the recordings, ask q's and it's a fairly straightforward class. Mark was very kind and approachable and told jokes to keep us engaged.

Such a sweet guy, but it's unfortunate that I found the course content dry and boring. He makes sure that his students are understanding the material and is always approachable for any questions you have. Highly recommend.
Love him. Take the class if you can get. His lectures are interesting and the in class quizes are "community/collabrative" so just show up and get an A.

Dr. Lechner is a nice guy but I dunno where he pulls his weekly quiz questions from. No exams which was nice but the 9 homework assignments were literal essays. BEWARE of the group project "make a resource for future classes". Class was scheduled 3x1hr lectures/week, he posted 6+ ADDITIONAL hrs of lectures per week, good intentions but overwhelming

He's an amazing prof. Genuinely cares about his students and their well-being. His lecture slides are quite long. Class is merely supplementary to his slides and assume you've gone through it on your own.

Mark's lectures can be challenging to understand sometimes, as they have many diagrams that you need to interpret. However, he always tries his best to clarify them in class/office hours when you ask. He's also generous marker when it comes to assignments. I thoroughly enjoyed being his student and would take a class with him again in a heartbeat.

Mark is a great guy, lots of office hours, available before and after class, replies to messages quickly. Very understanding and helpful. Group quizzes :) Complaints would be that he is way smarter than me so a lot of what he says goes over my head, his marking can be quite tricky and his practice exams are quite a bit easier than his actual exams.

If you're taking a class with Dr. Lechner be ready to have one of the best classes ever at SFU. He is super caring and nice to students, using 3x5 cards for feedback every lecture, has quite a lot of things to do but I found them useful and helpful to boost the grade. Don't be ashamed to ask him about homework/exams/assignments, he will help A LOT!

When it comes to tough courses like HSCI 321 or 324, it's BOUND to be tough regardless of prof. But the BEST of the best is Dr Lechner. He truly loves his students and wants nothing more than to help you understand. In 324, asks interactive questions, lets students work in groups for quizzes to help make it easier and truly is the best prof for 324

The course is hard, and difficult to understand at times. However, Dr. Lechner is a wonderful professor, which made it enjoyable. He is also an extremely intelligent and kind person, no wonder everybody likes him! Overall, I wish every professor would care as much as he does. THE BEST!

Absolutely increadible professor. Super knowledgeable, passionate, and caring towards students. The course is extremely difficult, however, and memorization heavy. Information is redundant and hard to follow. Although I didnt enjoy the content I would take any class with him!

Lecture slides are messy and hard to follow at times. His rubrics are not always clear. In class quizzes are easy enough and you get to work with other people. Tests are pretty tough and he doesn't explain the material very well at times.
Such a great prof! Super caring for students and very down to earth. Easy to talk to and approach and actually wants his students to do well.

Mark is the best prof at SFU for HSCI 324. The content can be challenging for some (especially for the first midterm -lots of calculation and memorization) but it gets much interesting later on and Mark's rubric is laid out in a way that you will do well if you come to class and do the quizzes every week (you can work with anyone)! TAKE IT

THE BEST PROF AT SFU by far. I find genetics very difficult, but if i had taken with anyone else I would've regretted it. He makes class interactive by having discussions etc. His grading rubric is great because there are a lot of areas you can do well and even if you don't do so well on the exams can still get a decent grade in the course.
He is a amazing professor, who cares for his students. One of the best professor in SFU!!!

Class itself is kind of boring but he can make it fun at times, key point is at times. His exams are not too difficult and is very generous with marks. He responds to emails in a timely manner and is always there for help. Super friendly and non intimidating. This class was super boring to me but he had creative ways to keep his class interested
Dr. Lechner is a great professor. He makes the lectures interesting and engaging. He is really helpful during his office hours so make sure to go.
very well organized class with lots of discussion, midterm and final was fair and directly from lectures...also always available for extra help and bonus points...
He is one of the best profs at SFU. He is very approachable and always available for extra help. His lectures are clear and organized.

Excellent professor!! Very nice lectures, powerpoint format. Good break down of marks. Open book quizzes, asks relevant questions on exams nothing too hard plus bonus marks! But you must work hard of course. Available for help, prompt responses. Great prof!!

Marks on an American scheme- A- is 90-93%; but has bonus marks, and is wiling to help outside of class. If you go to class, and go for all the bonus marks, it's not hard to pull at least an A if not A+ if you work for it.
